Award.AwardTitle: Integrating STEM and Digital Literacies with Adolescents

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As part of its overall effort to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants. In alignment with these aims, the STEM + Digital Literacies (STEM+L) project will investigate science fiction as an effective mechanism to attract and immerse adolescents (ages 10-13) from diverse cultural backgrounds in environmental and human health content and socio-scientific issues. This work is particularly novel, as the current knowledge base is limited, and largely addresses the high school level. Therefore, the results of the proposed effort could yield important findings regarding the feasibility of this activity as an effective platform for science learning and engagement for younger students. As such, STEM+L would not only advance knowledge in the field but would also contribute to a growing AISL portfolio on digital literacy and learning.

STEM+L is an early stage Innovations in Development project that will engage thirty middle school students in out of school time experiences. Over a twenty-four-week period, students will work collaboratively in groups in-person and online with their peers and field experts to design, develop, and produce STEM content rich, multimedia science fictions. The in-person learning experiences will take place on the University of Miami campus during the summer and academic year. Culminating activities include student presentations online and at a local Science Fiction Festival. The research component will employ an iterative, design-based approach. Four research questions will be explored: (a) How do students learn science concepts and multimodal digital literacies through participating in the STEM+L Academy? (b) How do students change their views in STEM related subject matter and in pursuing STEM related careers? (c) How do students participate in the STEM+L Academy? (d) How do we best support students' participation and learning of STEM+L in face-to-face and online environments? Data collection methods include video records, student-generated artifacts, online surveys, embedded assessments, interviews, and multimodal reflections. Comparative case analysis and a mixed methods approach will be employed. A rigorous evaluation will be conducted by a critical external review board. Inclusive and innovative dissemination strategies will ensure that the results of the research and program reach a broad range of audiences including both informal and formal STEM and literacy educators and researchers, learning scientists, local communities, and policy makers through national and international conference presentations, journal publications, Web2.0 resources, and community outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The exploratory STEM+L project used multimedia science fiction production as a mechanism to engage adolescent students in participating in integrated STEM and digital literacies practices. We implemented the program for two consecutive years (2017-8, 2018-9).

 

Intellectual Merit: The project developed and refined a multimedia composition platform (ikos.miami.edu) and generated a set of curriculum materials on the topic of Environment & Human Health and multimodal composition. In terms of research, the project studied the impact of the design features of role-taking and multimodal composition on patterns and trajectories of students? participation in STEM.

Our research has revealed several notable findings with respect to student learning. Some highlights include: (a) Students? trajectories of disciplinary identity development are coupled with their role-taking behaviors (e.g., for instance, most students who started with choosing a single role tended to end up with developing hybrid roles); (b) Multimodal composing offers multiple points of entry and different pathways for students to participate in STEM; (c) Students connect science practices in classrooms with those in professional domains and recognize science in non-science careers through taking the role of scientist; (d) Collaboration, cooperation, and competition co-exists in teamwork and enable different types of dynamics that shape students? participation trajectories.

With respect to developing instructional supports, we found: (a) Structured activities can be developed to simultaneously support disciplinary learning and multimodal composing, integrating individual and collaborative learning, and balancing prescribed STEM content and individualized interests and composing paths ; (b) Multimodal composing requires students to not only become familiar with a variety of tools, but to also know how to effectively integrate these modalities; (c) Disciplinary role-taking can be a powerful means for students to work on team-based, STEM projects; (d) Authentic audiences empower students to learn from experts (e.g., scientists, filmmakers) and to share their sci-fis in multiple venues; and (e) Student-generated multimodal narratives can be analyzed from different perspectives (e.g., orchestration of different modalities, how science is integrated via different modalities).

 

Broader Impacts: The STEM+L project developed new educational materials and resources (imaginefuture.org) targeting integrating STEM and digital literacies. In our two iterations, we enrolled a total of 65 participants with diverse cultural backgrounds (1/3 female students; 3/4 black or Hispanic/Latinx students) and 26 teachers/informal educators in two teacher workshops. It has resulted in 14 national and international conference presentations/proceedings, 5 papers published in peer-reviewed journals, 5 manuscripts under review or in progress, 1 book chapter, and 1 Ph.D. dissertation study. The project also produced two short videos for the NSF STEM for ALL Video Showcase.
